Hello Sergio,

Just as Nat said, those are definitely two testcases. They don't belong 
into one test method.

The first test would look like:

@Test(expected=...)
public void xxx() {
     DriverManager.getConnection(badConnString);
}

That's it.

But I see another common anti-pattern in the second part of the code you 
showed:

Sergio Bobillier wrote:
> try
> {
> connection = DriverManager.getConnection(goodConnString);
> }
> catch(SQLException sEx)
> {
> fail(SQLException was not expected but was thrown");
> }

The JUnit Rule is: Don't catch exceptions that you don't expect! Declare 
them as throws instead.
So it would be better to do:

@Test
public void xxx() throws SQLException {
     connection = DriverManager.getConnection(goodConnString);
     //....
     assertXXXX
}

The problem with the first approach of catching the exception and then 
failing is, that you loose all the information about the exception. And 
it's a lot wordier too.
Should an unexpected exception occur, will it fail the test anyways and 
in addition you get the stacktrace in JUnit, to analyse the root problem.

Greetings,
    Malte
